speaker: ME
text: My name is Freek Van Ponnen .

speaker: ME
text: We have we uh have been doing research in a usability lab

speaker: ME
text: where we observed um users operating remote controls .

speaker: ME
text: Uh we let them fill out a questionnaire .

speaker: ME
text: We had one hundred of these uh test subjects .

speaker: ME
text: Uh in addition we did some market research . Uh see what the market consists of . What ages are involved .

speaker: ME
text: these are three quite astonishing results , I thought .

speaker: ME
text: Um remotes are being considered ugly .

speaker: ME
text: uh seventy five percent of the um people questioned uh indicated that they thought their remote were was ugly .

speaker: ME
text: Um and an additional eighty percent indicated that they would spend more money on a fancy-looking remote control .

speaker: ME
text: Um in addition remotes were not very functional .

speaker: ME
text: Fifty percent of the people indicated they only loo used about ten percent of the buttons on a remote control .

speaker: ME
text: And fifty percent of the people indicated that their remote tended to get lost in their room .

speaker: ME
text: Then we did some research to the most relevant functions .

speaker: ME
text: Channel selection and volume selection um both got a ten on a scale of one to ten for relevancy .

speaker: ME
text: The power button got a nine .

speaker: ME
text: And teletext got a six and a half .

speaker: ME
text: So these are the most most uh important functions on a remote control .

speaker: ME
text: Then there are some one-time use function .

speaker: ME
text: That's what I like to call them .

speaker: ME
text: That uh audio settings , video settings , and channel settings buttons .

speaker: ME
text: Which are not really used very frequently ,

speaker: ME
text: but are still considered to be of some importance .

speaker: ME
text: Um channel selection was also indicated to be used very frequently . One hundred and sixty eight times per hour .

speaker: ME
text: Um sixty percent of the market consists of users between the ages sixteen and forty f six .

speaker: ME
text: Um <disfmarker> Main characteristic of this group is that they're very critical on the remote control .

speaker: ME
text: Um they like to use new f new functions .

speaker: ME
text: But they also are very critical .

speaker: ME
text: They won't spend their money very easily .

speaker: ME
text: the users of forty six to sixty five years cons The make up forty percent of the market .

speaker: ME
text: They are not really very interested in features .

speaker: ME
text: But they do tend to spend their money a lot easier .

speaker: ME
text: What I think this indicates for our um design . I think we should make a remote for the future .

speaker: ME
text: And this means we would um have to focus on the age ages sixteen to forty five .

speaker: ME
text: Uh this also makes up most the biggest part of the market ,

speaker: ME
text: so that will also be where our main profit would be gettable .

speaker: ME
text: Um this would mean we would have to make a fancy design .

speaker: ME
text: Um <disfmarker> The results also indicated that um about one quarter of the people questioned thought that the remote control caused R_S_ R_S_I_ .

speaker: ME
text: Um this is certainly something to take into account .

speaker: ME
text: And thirty four percent thought that it was hard to learn a n how to operate a new control , remote control .

speaker: ME
text: So these are two factors that I think should be included in the design .

speaker: ME
text: Besides of course that the remote must look very nice .

speaker: ME
text: And the functionality <disfmarker> As a lot of people indicated , they only use about ten percent of the buttons ,

speaker: ME
text: I think we should make very few buttons .

speaker: ME
text: Uh this will also be uh beneficial to the design of the remote .

speaker: ME
text: Uh I think the most frequently used buttons should be emphasised . Especially the channel selection and audio uh selection buttons .

speaker: ME
text: and so they should be robust .

speaker: ME
text: Um <disfmarker> Then as mo as a lot of people indicated that their um remote got lost in the room ,

speaker: ME
text: because it would um certainly boost the uh production costs a lot .

speaker: ME
text: But it might be a good idea to make a docking station .

speaker: ME
text: And this would , could get a button in it

speaker: ME
text: which would send a signal to the remote

speaker: ME
text: So you'd know where it is in the room .

speaker: ME
text: And in addition to this it could um recharge the batteries in the remote if you put it in .

speaker: ME
text: Then um a surprisingly great deal of people w indicated that um an L_C_D_ screen in the remote control would be preferred .

speaker: ME
text: This was um mostly people in the age of sixteen to twenty five .

speaker: ME
text: But up till forty five it remains feasible .

speaker: ME
text: This would also greatly increase the production costs

speaker: ME
text: but I think these are just some small factors we could consider .
